Assange: Fox News Analyst Is Promoting Terrorism Against Me

Julian Assange gave his first cable news interview since his release from jail to MSNBC's Cenk Uygur on Wednesday, and he had harsh words for both politi...

A pretty good interview with him over here. Worth a watch, by anyone.

[/quote]

They recently started airing top gear over here, or maybe it’s an american version of it, either way, it sucks. The commercial is a guy driving a 4 door and going “100, 115, 130, 145, WOW 145mph in a 4 door!”, shut up, your an idiot, there have been countless 4 door cars capable of doing that for years, idiot… Looks like the worst show in all of history.[/quote]
my dads car can go that fast !!

item.title: Wikileaks
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

I wanted to give the US version a chance. I watched an episode of it, and couldn’t believe the BBC would license it out to these idiots. It is such a bad thing for the Top Gear name.

They should have gone their own way with it, not try to copy the original - because the original version works because of the presenters - that didn’t really even start off to try and be presenters. They’re not typical at all, and work so well together.

You’d know if it was the British version as soon as you saw Jeremy Clarkson. He is the ultimate stereotypical brit, HORRIBLE teeth, and he has a rather strong accent (at least to outsider).

Read full topic

item.title: Wikileaks
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

BBC Controversies are anything from a presenter joking about someones political views (a little more serious) to a brand of clothing the weather reporter is using. The reason? Because we pay for the entire organisation. They have to answer to us, and anything that could be seen as the BBC not acting responsibly in regards to their situation, even if it is an accident - you’ll get loads of people complaining, forcing action or apology.

The only exceptions seem to be Top Gear. Clarkson gets away with saying whatever he wants, and because it rarely ever anything serious - it can be safely shrugged off…

Read full topic

item.title: Wikileaks
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

[quote=“mwiebelhaus, post:113, topic:371581”][quote author=Radeon link=topic=467665.msg3429818#msg3429818 date=1292227966]

Everyones view of Fox News is distorted.

I think it’s very clear that Fox News aims to only manipulate public opinion to suit the American war machine.

en.wikipedia.org

Fox News controversies

Fox News (officially, Fox News Channel, FNC) is an American basic cable and satellite television channel. It has been the subject of several controversies and allegations. Fox News has been alleged by academics, media figures, political figures, and watchdog groups of having Republican Party bias in their news coverage as well as perpetuating more general views of a conservative bias. Fox News has publicly denied such charges, stating that the reporters in the newsroom provide separate, neutral...

[/quote]
Cool story bro but

en.wikipedia.org

BBC controversies

This article outlines, in chronological order, the various scandals surrounding or involving the BBC that have occurred. The BBC was established as the privately controlled British Broadcasting Company in 1922. In 1926 the unions called for a General Strike and the Conservative Government feared the outbreak of revolution, as had happened in Russia in 1917. Labour Party politicians such as Ramsay MacDonald and Philip Snowden criticised the BBC for being pro-Government and anti-Unions; however, ...


en.wikipedia.org

CNN controversies

Cable News Network (CNN), an American basic cable and satellite television channel, has been the subject of several controversies. This article recounts controversies and allegations relating to both the domestic version of CNN, and its sister channels CNN International and CNN-News18. CNN has often been the subject of allegations of party bias. In research conducted by the Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard University and the Project for Excellence in Journalism...


http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_controversies[/quote]

I can’t be stuffed comparing each but after skipping through a few of the BBC controversies, they don’t sound anywhere near as serious as the fox ones.

Read full topic

en.wikipedia.org

CBS News

CBS News is the news division of American television and radio service CBS. The president of CBS News is David Rhodes. CBS News' broadcasts include the CBS Evening News, CBS This Morning, news magazine programs CBS Sunday Morning, 60 Minutes and 48 Hours, and Sunday morning political affairs program Face the Nation. CBS News Radio produces hourly newscasts for hundreds of radio stations, while CBS also operates a 24-hour news network called CBSN. In 1929, the Columbia Broadcasting System began ...


[/quote]
